commit_message:
Add the new Keystone TokenModel

This commit adds the new Keystone TokenModel that will be used to
unify in-memory references for tokens. The initial implementation
of this model works similarly to the AccessInfo model from
keystoneclient, providing a unified set of properties that will
return the data from the token-version specific locations.

Future development will round this model out to be better suited
as an authoratative token data source that can be transformed into
any token format / version.

Change-Id: I341e03ac8483f8d6085f4c2c218a28647b9ff2e4
bp: non-persistent-tokens
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/17/106917/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Descriptor objects for the in-memory token data structure.""" import abc import weakref from keystoneclient.common import cms from keystoneclient import utils as ksc_utils import six from sqlalchemy import util as sqla_util from keystone.common import config from keystone.common import dependency from keystone import exception from keystone.openstack.common.gettextutils import _ from keystone.openstack.common import jsonutils from keystone.openstack.common import log from keystone.openstack.common import timeutils from keystone import token CONF = config.CONF LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) class InvalidTokenPrimitive(Exception): """An internal-only exception used to indicate a dict was created from KeystoneToken.to_primitive method. This exception should not ever get exposed outside of the KeystoneToken class. """ @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class TokenDescriptor(object): def __init__(self, default): self.default = default self.data = weakref.WeakKeyDictionary() def __get__(self, instance, owner): if instance is None: # NOTE(morganfainberg): If we don't have an instance, this is being # called at the class level, we want to in-fact return the self # object so we can interact with it directly. return self return self.data.get(instance, self.default) @abc.abstractmethod def __set__(self, instance, value): self.data[instance] = value def to_primitive(self, instance): """A descriptor specific method of returning the "primitive". Some data types (e.g. trust, user) will only want to store the ID not the complete object, this is a class-specific method that is meant to be overridden as needed to extract the primitive for the KeystoneToken object ``to_primitive`` method. :param instance: The instance object that the value should be associated with. :return: the primitive based on the value argument """ return self.data[instance] def from_primitive(self, instance, value): """A descriptor specific method to restore from the "primitive". Some data types may have special handling for restoring from the primitive value (e.g. ISOTIME strings), which should be handled in a different manner than simply issuing a __set__ with the primitive value. :param instance: Instance the property descriptor is being accessed from :param value: the primitive value """ self.__set__(instance, value) class TokenDescriptorIdPrimitive(TokenDescriptor): def to_primitive(self, instance): return self.data[instance]['id'] @dependency.requires('trust_api') class TokenTrust(TokenDescriptorIdPrimitive): """Object that does the lookup of the trust ref based on trust_id. Behind the scenes, the trust_id is converted to the trust_ref if trusts are enabled. """ def __set__(self, instance, value): if CONF.trust.enabled: self.data[instance] = sqla_util.immutabledict( self.trust_api.get_trust(value)) class TokenDatetime(TokenDescriptor): def __get__(self, instance, owner): """Get the value, if no value is set, set a sane default. If the time data has no value yet, set the value, ensure the stored value is always ISOTIME format. Return the DATETIME object format when accessed. """ if instance is None: # NOTE(morganfainberg): If we don't have an instance, this is being # called at the class level, we want to in-fact return the self # object so we can interact with it directly. return self timedata = None if instance not in self.data: if callable(self.default): # NOTE(morganfainberg): The default is a callable, call the # function instead of using the direct value as the default. timedata = self.default() else: timedata = self.default self.data[instance] = timeutils.isotime(timedata, subsecond=True) if timedata is None: timedata = timeutils.normalize_time( timeutils.parse_isotime(self.data[instance])) return timedata def __set__(self, instance, value): # Always serialize the time-format to isotime self.data[instance] = timeutils.isotime(value, subsecond=True) def from_primitive(self, instance, value): # NOTE(morganfainberg): the primitive in this case should always be # an ISOTIME string. Since we do serialization/deserialization on these # strings during __get__ and __set__ calls, we can simply store the # value again, no __set__ serialization logic required. self.data[instance] = value @dependency.requires('assignment_api') class TokenDomain(TokenDescriptorIdPrimitive): """Object that does the lookup of the domain ref based on domain_id. Behind the scenes, the domain_id is converted to the filtered domain_ref. """ def __set__(self, instance, value): domain_data = self.assignment_api.get_domain(value) self.data[instance] = sqla_util.immutabledict( {'id': domain_data['id'], 'name': domain_data['name']}) class DomainAwareDescriptorValueDict(dict): """This is a domain aware object that acts like a dictionary. This object allows for re-use of the Domain descriptor within other descriptors such as Project and User. """ domain = TokenDomain(None) def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): domain = kwargs.pop('domain', None) super(DomainAwareDescriptorValueDict, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self['domain'] = self.domain if domain is not None: self.domain = domain def __setitem__(self, key, value): if key == 'domain': self.domain = value else: super(DomainAwareDescriptorValueDict, self).__setitem__(key, value) @dependency.requires('assignment_api') class TokenProject(TokenDescriptorIdPrimitive): """Object that does the lookup of the project ref based on project_id. Behind the scenes, the project_id is converted to the filtered project_ref. """ def __set__(self, instance, value): project_data = self.assignment_api.get_project(value) data_obj = DomainAwareDescriptorValueDict( id=project_data['id'], name=project_data['name'], domain=project_data['domain_id']) self.data[instance] = sqla_util.immutabledict(data_obj) @dependency.requires('identity_api') class TokenUser(TokenDescriptorIdPrimitive): """Object that does the lookup of the user ref based on user_id. Behind the scenes, the user_id is converted to the filtered user_ref. """ def __set__(self, instance, value): user_data = self.identity_api.get_user(value) data_obj = DomainAwareDescriptorValueDict( id=user_data['id'], name=user_data['name'], domain=user_data['domain_id']) self.data[instance] = sqla_util.immutabledict(data_obj) @dependency.optional('oauth_api') class TokenOAuth(TokenDescriptor): def __set__(self, instance, value): if self.oauth_api: oauth_data = self.oauth_api.get_access_token(value) self.data[instance] = sqla_util.immutabledict( {'access_token_id': oauth_data['id'], 'consumer_id': oauth_data['consumer_id'], 'role_ids': jsonutils.loads(oauth_data['role_ids'])}) @dependency.requires('assignment_api') class KeystoneTokenModel(object): """The Keystone in-memory token object. This object represents the in-memory token object that unifies all token versions. The full data set needed to issue, validate, and interact with a given token is contained within this object. """ # This value will be used to determine if a dictionary retrieved from a # token persistence backend was serialized with the # KeystoneToken.to_primitive method. If this key exists and is set to True # the backend can/will try and use KeystoneToken.from_primitive() instead # of the KeystoneToken.from_serialized_token method. primitive_serializer_key = '_TO_PRIMITIVE_FROM_KEYSTONETOKEN' expires_at = TokenDatetime(token.default_expire_time) issued_at = TokenDatetime(timeutils.utcnow) domain = TokenDomain(None) project = TokenProject(None) oauth = TokenOAuth(None) trust = TokenTrust(None) user = TokenUser(None) # Descriptors that will be converted to primitive values when # .to_primitive() is called. _to_primitive_attrs = frozenset(['expires_at', 'issued_at', 'domain', 'project', 'oauth', 'trust', 'user']) # Attributes that will be included in the primitive dict when # .to_primitive() is called. These must be python primitives, and if this # is not the case, the attribute should be converted to a descriptor that # can handle this conversion. _include_in_to_primitive = frozenset(['is_admin', 'includes_catalog', 'token_id', 'short_id', 'bind', 'roles']) @ksc_utils.positional(1) def __init__(self, token_id, includes_catalog, is_admin): self._token_id = token_id self._short_id = cms.cms_hash_token(self.token_id, mode=CONF.token.hash_algorithm) self.is_admin = is_admin self.includes_catalog = includes_catalog self.bind = {} self.roles = [] self.frozen = False def __setattr__(self, key, value): if self.frozen: # NOTE(morganfainberg): Once a token has been issued or if it is # loaded from a set of primitives, it is frozen. Nothing should # ever change the values of the token after that point. raise AttributeError(_('Values of a token cannot be changed once ' 'the token has been loaded or issued.')) if ((self.project is not None and key == 'domain') or (self.domain is not None and key == 'project')): raise exception.ValidationError(_('A token cannot be scoped to ' 'both a project and domain.')) super(KeystoneTokenModel, self).__setattr__(key, value) @property def short_id(self): return self._short_id @property def token_id(self): return self._token_id @token_id.setter def token_id(self, value): self._token_id = value self._short_id = cms.cms_hash_token(self.token_id, mode=CONF.token.hash_algorithm) def freeze(self): """Mark the token as frozen (cannot be changed). This is done automatically when the token is serialized, or if the token was loaded either from primitives or a serialized format. If the token is already frozen, there is nothing to do. """ if not self.frozen: self.frozen = True def populate_roles(self): """Populate the token roles based upon data that exists in the model. This method will perform the heavy lifting of querying the assignment_api to determine the roles the token should contain. This should be the last action performed before serializing the token or marking the token as frozen. Calling this method a second time will repopulate the roles which is an expensive operation unless the token is marked as frozen. A frozen token will ignore requests to repopulate the roles. """ if self.frozen: return # Handle the OAuth case if self.oauth is not None: all_roles = self.assignment_api.list_roles() # A tuple of immutabledict containing the role_id and role_name # of each role in the authorized role list for the OAuth # access token. self.roles = tuple([sqla_util.immutabledict({'id': x['id'], 'name': x['name']}) for x in all_roles if x['id'] in self.oauth['role_ids']]) return # Handle the non OAuth case if self.trust is not None: user_id = self.trust['trustor_user_id'] project_id = self.trust['project_id'] domain_id = None else: user_id = self.user['id'] project_id = self.project['id'] domain_id = self.domain['id'] if project_id or domain_id: roles = self._get_roles_for_user(user_id=user_id, domain_id=domain_id, project_id=project_id) filtered_roles = [] if self.trust is not None: trust_roles = set([x['id'] for x in self.trust.roles]) for role in roles: if role['id'] in trust_roles: filtered_roles.append( sqla_util.immutabledict({'id': role['id'], 'name': role['name']})) else: raise exception.Forbidden( _('Trustee has no delegated roles.')) else: filtered_roles = [sqla_util.immutabledict({'id': x['id'], 'name': x['name']}) for x in roles] if not filtered_roles: if project_id: msg = _('User %(user_id)s has no access ' 'to project %(project_id)s') % { 'user_id': user_id, 'project_id': project_id} else: msg = _('User %(user_id)s has no access ' 'to domain %(domain_id)s') % { 'user_id': user_id, 'domain_id': domain_id} LOG.debug(msg) raise exception.Unauthorized(msg) self.roles = tuple(filtered_roles) @ksc_utils.positional(1) def _get_roles_for_user(self, user_id, domain_id, project_id): roles = [] if domain_id: roles = self.assignment_api.get_roles_for_user_and_domain( user_id, domain_id) if project_id: roles = self.assignment_api.get_roles_for_user_and_project( user_id, project_id) return [self.assignment_api.get_role(role_id) for role_id in roles] @classmethod def from_serialized_token(cls, token_data): # TODO(morganfainberg): Consume a serialized token and convert to an # instantiation of the KeystoneTokenModel object. pass def serialize_token(self, formatter): self.freeze() # TODO(morganfainberg): Serialize the token def to_primitive(self): """Convert the token to a dictionary of python primitive values. The ability to convert the unified token object to a simple set of python primitives important when dealing with the token-persistence backends as each backend has differing requirements for data formats. To ensure no unsupported data types are stored in a given backend, this method will convert the token data to a primitive-only format. :return: dictionary of python primitive values """ primitives = {} for attr in self._to_primitive_attrs: primitives[attr] = getattr( KeystoneTokenModel, attr).to_primitive(self) for attr in self._include_in_to_primitive: primitives[attr] = getattr(self, attr) # Indicate this was a serialization from the primitives[self.primitive_serializer_key] = True return primitives @classmethod def from_primitive(cls, primitive_token_fmt): """Convert the token from the primitive format back to the object. This method is the inverse of the ``to_primitive`` method, which will convert the primitive token data back to the in-memory object format. :param primitive_token_fmt: dictionary of python primitives that can be converted to a full token object :return: instantiated KeystoneToken object """ if not isinstance(primitive_token_fmt, dict): raise exception.ValidationError( _('Primitive "%r" is not a dict.') % primitive_token_fmt) if cls.primitive_serializer_key not in primitive_token_fmt: raise InvalidTokenPrimitive() token_obj = KeystoneTokenModel( token_id=primitive_token_fmt['token_id'], includes_catalog=primitive_token_fmt['includes_catalog'], is_admin=primitive_token_fmt['is_admin']) token_obj.bind = primitive_token_fmt['bind'] token_obj.roles = primitive_token_fmt['roles'] for attr in KeystoneTokenModel._to_primitive_attrs: value = primitive_token_fmt.get(attr) if value is not None: getattr(KeystoneTokenModel, attr).from_primitive(token_obj, value) token_obj.freeze() return token_obj

commit_message:
Silences the output in CLI for connection info

This change try to reduce the useless urllib3 connection info in
CLI by set the log level of urllib3.connectionpool.

Change-Id: I9d21d29ae0274133099dd05a14e5211d77ffe721
Closes-Bug: #1333485

commit_message:
ssl: Add support for multiple CA certificates

In some circumstances, more than one CA certificate may need to be
installed in order to enable proper SSL connections internally
(i.e. OpenStack services communicating with each other) and
externally (i.e. Keystone communicating with LDAPS, or Cinder with
an SSL-enabled Zadara).

This change turns the single SSLCACertificate input into a
CommaDelimitedList value.

Change-Id: I59317629d53f5cfb2ad07cee08015784eafb5a57
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/55/109355/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ssl_ca_certificates: {Ref: SSLCACertificates}

commit_message:
Do not allow wheels for stable tests

The tests against stable versions of consuming projects download the
release packages from the PyPI mirror. Now that there are wheels
available, installing those packages breaks. Rather than completely
rewrite the test scripts, force the sdist to be downloaded.

Change-Id: I574610b934a40aa4e4c017d1f247cc14b81a8160

remove static files from docs

Since we are already using oslosphinx, there is no reason to
host our own version of the usual static files.

deleted_lines: /** * Sphinx stylesheet -- default theme * ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ */ @import url("basic.css"); /* -- page layout ----------------------------------------------------------- */ body { font-family: sans-serif; git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/42/109142/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright (c) 2014 Rackspace Hosting All Rights Reserved. Author: Jordan Cazamias <jordan.cazamias@rackspace.com> Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. Quotas ====== Overview -------- The quotas extension can be used to retrieve a tenant's absolute limits. *Note*: Quotas is an extension and needs to be enabled before it can be used. If Designate returns a 404 error, ensure that the following line has been added to the designate.conf file:: enabled_extensions_v2 = quotas Once this line has been added, restart the designate-central and designate-api processes. Get Quotas ---------- .. http:get:: /quotas/TENANT_ID Retrieves quotas for tenant with the specified TENANT_ID. The following example retrieves the quotas for tenant 12345. **Example request:** .. sourcecode:: http GET /v2/quotas/12345 HTTP/1.1 Host: 127.0.0.1:9001 Accept: application/json Content-Type: application/json **Example response:** .. sourcecode:: http HTTP/1.1 201 Created Content-Type: application/json { "quota": { "zones": 10, "recordset_records": 20, "zone_records": 500, "zone_recordsets": 500 } } :form zones: Number of zones the tenant is allowed to own :form recordset_records: Number of records allowed per recordset :form zone_records: Number of records allowed per zone :form zone_recordsets: Number of recordsets allowed per zone :statuscode 200: Success :statuscode 401: Access Denied Update Quotas ------------- .. http:patch:: /quotas/TENANT_ID Updates the specified quota(s) to their new values. **Example request:** .. sourcecode:: http PATCH /v2/quotas/12345 HTTP/1.1 Host: 127.0.0.1:9001 Accept: application/json Content-Type: application/json { "quota": { "zones": 1000, "zone_records": 50 } } **Example response:** .. sourcecode:: http HTTP/1.1 200 OK Vary: Accept Content-Type: application/json { "quota": { "zones": 1000, "recordset_records": 20, "zone_records": 50, "zone_recordsets": 500 } } :statuscode 200: Success :statuscode 401: Access Denied

commit_message:
Change V2 image tests to actually run V2 image code

The current tests for image do not run v2 image code, changing
that portion also made it's only test fail.
I opted to change the image delete code and not the test, since
passing the object ID is more in line with the rest of the
project code.

Change-Id: I62e13c063a5d68279dbbf31e59266db6285d73bf

added_lines: <title>Operating system and hypervisor</title> <para> The selection of operating system (OS) and hypervisor has a significant impact on the end point design. Selecting a particular operating system and hypervisor could affect server hardware selection. For example, a selected combination needs to be supported on the selected hardware. Ensuring the storage hardware selection and topology supports the selected operating system and hypervisor combination should also be considered. Additionally, make sure that the networking hardware selection and topology will work with the chosen operating system and hypervisor combination. For example, if the design uses Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP), the hypervisor needs to support it. </para>

subject: OVS agent: Correct bridge setup ordering
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-03 11:01:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e24175a08926965b6e4ba9faec80ae8cc80642a2', 'message': 'OVS agent: Correct bridge setup ordering

This patch fixes three issues that combined to break tunnel networks.

The first issue was the the failure mode was being set on the
integration bridge after the canary flow was installed. This
immediately wiped out the canary flow.

The second problem was that the main loop would sync tunnel networks
right before resetting the tunnel bridge when the canary flow was
missing. This meant that it would sync all of the tunnels via RPC and
then wipe them out.

The final issue was that after resetting the tunnel bridge in the
main loop, the tunnel_sync variable was not set to True, so the
tunnels would never be resynchronized.

This patch addresses the three issues in the following ways:
1. Set the failure mode on the bridge before the canary flow is
installed.
2. Run the OVS restart logic before the tunnel synchronization.
3. If the restart logic is triggered, set tunnel_sync to True to
trigger synchronization.

Conflicts:
	neutron/tests/unit/openvswitch/test_ovs_tunnel.py

commit_message:
OVS agent: Correct bridge setup ordering

This patch fixes three issues that combined to break tunnel networks.

The first issue was the the failure mode was being set on the
integration bridge after the canary flow was installed. This
immediately wiped out the canary flow.

The second problem was that the main loop would sync tunnel networks
right before resetting the tunnel bridge when the canary flow was
missing. This meant that it would sync all of the tunnels via RPC and
then wipe them out.

The final issue was that after resetting the tunnel bridge in the
main loop, the tunnel_sync variable was not set to True, so the
tunnels would never be resynchronized.

This patch addresses the three issues in the following ways:
1. Set the failure mode on the bridge before the canary flow is
installed.
2. Run the OVS restart logic before the tunnel synchronization.
3. If the restart logic is triggered, set tunnel_sync to True to
trigger synchronization.

Conflicts:
	neutron/tests/unit/openvswitch/test_ovs_tunnel.py

Closes-Bug: #1292105
Change-Id: I6381e3fee49910127c420dd2e3205c64cdb9e185
(cherry-picked from commit 0e5c50ecb2e2317ca6908a9bcec3bcb8ca6d3af8)

commit_message:
Do not query neutron-server for device_id if in cache

If you reboot the dhcp-agent it will query the neturon-server
once per network for device_id though it already knows this
information as it was returned in the initial get_active_networks_info call.
This patch speeds up the sync state performance by an exponential factor.

Change-Id: I8fc92ef1182b8eb71f9454611ec2dff27367cbcb
Closes-bug: #1305265

subject: Work around for auto_schedule_networks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-24 19:33:54.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/scheduler/dhcp_agent_scheduler.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0055b5f5b463271d8ec38df5c7e61eb1e81966f6', 'message': "Work around for auto_schedule_networks

Previously, whenever auto_schedule_networks() networks would be called
it would move networks that were mapped to one dhcp-agent to another
dhcp-agent if there status was reporting down. The problem with this
is that it didn't remove the network mapping from the previous dhcp-agent.
Since the status implementation on the agents isn't very robust eventually
all networks will be mapped to every dhcp-agent. This patch avoids
this by not taking the status into account for networks that already
exist. Newly created networks though will be mapped to agents with an
active status.

Change-Id: I7b20f48c30c4cf630f5ff654babb84865ef646ef
"}]
commit_message:
Work around for auto_schedule_networks

Previously, whenever auto_schedule_networks() networks would be called
it would move networks that were mapped to one dhcp-agent to another
dhcp-agent if there status was reporting down. The problem with this
is that it didn't remove the network mapping from the previous dhcp-agent.
Since the status implementation on the agents isn't very robust eventually
all networks will be mapped to every dhcp-agent. This patch avoids
this by not taking the status into account for networks that already
exist. Newly created networks though will be mapped to agents with an
active status.

Change-Id: I7b20f48c30c4cf630f5ff654babb84865ef646ef

commit_message:
Don't expect replies from mute cells

Broadcast messages were failing if a cell stopped responding. We now
only send broadcast messages that need replies to cells that are not
mute.

Closes-bug: #1312468
Change-Id: If242e44535d455894b23af37d6c4aa3d09bb5395

the switch port's ACLs accordingly.

commit_message:
Fixes Hyper-V agent security group ICMP rules

Converts ICMP protocol to the equivalent protocol number.
Adds default ICMP reject rules.
Adds default ANY protocol rules if the rule does not
contain any protocol.

Closes-Bug: #1299159
Change-Id: Iff51a58fdb532eda0fe7a63abf96004ee74bb073
(cherry picked from commit f56972193be903c67cd54c57bcc2becf6222aced)

commit_message:
Register LBaaS resources to quotas engine

Adding register_quotas=True argument to
resource_helper.build_resource_info() function
in order to register LBaaS resources to quotas engine

This change is actually a continuation of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/69803
change which was already approved

Change-Id: Ib75027ce4a1bea3d453f57b107d29546ec6743e5

commit_message:
Set python hash seed to 0 in tox.ini

New tox (>=1.7.0) sets a random python hash seed by default. This is
generally good for testing because it will help keep projects working
regardless of the hash seed, but designate unittests don't currently
pass with a random hash seed so set it to the python default seed.

This change will allow us to use new tox again and remove the
restriction on tox<=1.6.1 to run unittests.

Note this change will need to be backported to the stable branches to
keep unittests there working with new tox as well.

See also Ib54364877a251db48c54dfdc43c503281ea1f04a

Change-Id: I3b3d152148a2055da1e2eaef5f4fbb63ebbde6fa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/44/109744/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Note the hash seed is set to 0 until designate can be tested with a # random hash seed successfully. setenv = PYTHONHASHSEED=0

commit_message:
Set python hash seed to 0 in tox.ini

New tox (>=1.7.0) sets a random python hash seed by default. This is
generally good for testing because it will help keep projects working
regardless of the hash seed, but designate unittests don't currently
pass with a random hash seed so set it to the python default seed.

This change will allow us to use new tox again and remove the
restriction on tox<=1.6.1 to run unittests.

Note this change will need to be backported to the stable branches to
keep unittests there working with new tox as well.

See also Ib54364877a251db48c54dfdc43c503281ea1f04a

Change-Id: I3b3d152148a2055da1e2eaef5f4fbb63ebbde6fa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/40/109740/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Note the hash seed is set to 0 until designate can be tested with a # random hash seed successfully. setenv = PYTHONHASHSEED=0

commit_message:
Revert "Fix CLI support for DVR"

This reverts commit bfec80a776a53b554a8f2d023d2974539edef3ce.

This patch needs to be reverted until we resolve the issue with
patch 109180.

The previous change introduced a situation where we can only
override the default server side setting from the client side
for "--distributed" when the default is False. But we cannot
override when the default is True.

This is a requirement for DVR and at the same time we don't
want to introduce any new changes that would affect any current
plugins. So we will decide on it later and in the mean while I
will revert it.

Partial-Bug: #1346121
Partial-Bug: #1347960
Change-Id: I261f9e232b1f72ed0cb2f0c1ba218facaba9afcb

commit_message:
Mistral DSL and Heat template parsers

* Primarily for UI work but may be applicable to the Solum control plane
* Get an ordered task list from a Mistral DSL
* Get a sorted list of Mistral DSL required user input fields
* Get a list of Heat template required user input fields and metadata
* Ability to define the start Mistral Task when parsing
* May generate SVG GUI diagrams of Mistral workflows
* SVG diagrams are resizable now

Change-Id: I71ebbc99568cb347a9d676656765a3654dc7c72b

"""Mistral DSL and Heat template (HoT) parsing routines TODO(paulmo): * Add task(s) to Mistral DSL required input (a description for the UI) * Add unit tests * Add exception checking everywhere * Translate to Solum exceptions * Add internationalization """ import re def get_mistral_task_list(data_list): """Returns an ordered Mistral task list from a DSL Assumptions/notes: * Require proper YAML indentions * Require no circular workflows * Performs case insensitive searches for Mistral key words * Code ignores blank lines and comment lines (starting with '#') * A single "tasks:" label precedes the Mistral Task enumeration * Assuming that "on-success:" is logically equal to "on-finish:" labels * "on-success:"/"on-finish:" and "on-error:" may or may not exist * Only the last Task will have no "on-success:" or "on-finish:" * Code skips Mistral Tasks with only "on-error:" workflows (error handlers) """ task_list = [] workflow_pos = -1 curr_pos = 0 curr_name = None curr_success = None curr_error = None for line in data_list: line = line.rstrip() line_len = len(line) if line_len < 1: continue if line.lstrip()[0] == '#': continue lower_line = line.lower() if workflow_pos == -1: workflow_pos = lower_line.find("tasks:") continue if curr_name is None: curr_pos = line_len - len(line.lstrip()) line = line.lstrip() curr_name = line.rstrip(':') continue line_start_pos = line_len - len(line.lstrip()) if line_start_pos <= curr_pos: if curr_name is not None: task_list.append([curr_name, curr_success, curr_error]) curr_pos = line_len - len(line.lstrip()) line = line.lstrip() curr_name = line.rstrip(':') curr_success = None curr_error = None if line_start_pos <= workflow_pos: break continue val_pos = lower_line.find("on-success:") if val_pos != -1: curr_success = line[(val_pos + len("on-success:")):] curr_success = curr_success.lstrip() continue val_pos = lower_line.find("on-finish:") if val_pos != -1: curr_success = line[(val_pos + len("on-finish:")):] curr_success = curr_success.lstrip() continue val_pos = lower_line.find("on-error:") if val_pos != -1: curr_error = line[(val_pos + len("on-error:")):] curr_error = curr_error.lstrip() continue if curr_name is not None: task_list.append([curr_name, curr_success, curr_error]) sorted_task_list = [] curr_task_name = None for task in task_list: if task[1] is None: curr_task_name = task[0] sorted_task_list.insert(0, task) break if len(sorted_task_list) != 1: return None # TODO(paulmo) thow exception later? for count in range(len(task_list) - 1): for task in task_list: if task[1] == curr_task_name: curr_task_name = task[0] sorted_task_list.insert(0, task) break return sorted_task_list def get_mistral_required_input(data_list): """Returns required Mistral DSL user input field information Assumptions/notes: * Require proper YAML indentions * Performs case insensitive searches for Mistral key words * Code ignores blank lines and comment lines (starting with '#') * A single "output:" label precedes output variables * This code removes duplicate input values and sorts list * All variables are prefixed with "$." * Input variable names are a-z, A-Z, 0-9, _ and . characters only """ var_list = [] output_list = [] output_section = False output_spaces = 0 for line in data_list: line = line.rstrip() line_len = len(line) if line_len < 1: continue if line.lstrip()[0] == '#': continue lower_line = line.lower() output_pos = lower_line.find("output:") if output_pos != -1: output_section = True output_spaces = output_pos continue line_start = line_len - len(line.lstrip(' ')) if output_section: if line_start <= output_spaces: output_section = False match = re.search('\$\.([a-zA-Z0-9_.]*)', line) if match: var_name = match.group(0)[2:] if var_name.startswith("__"): continue if output_section: if var_name not in output_list: output_list.append(var_name) else: if var_name not in var_list: var_list.append(var_name) var_list.sort() output_list.sort() return var_list, output_list def get_heat_required_input(data_list): """Returns Heat required user input fields Assumptions/notes: * Require proper YAML indentions * Performs case insensitive searches for Mistral key words * Code ignores blank lines and comment lines (starting with '#') * A single "parameters:" label precedes output variables * Parameter name is always present but type, desc and default might not be """ var_list = [] param_pos = -1 in_params = False curr_name = None curr_name_start = 0 curr_type = None curr_desc = None curr_default = None for line in data_list: line = line.rstrip() line_len = len(line) if line_len < 1: continue if line.lstrip()[0] == '#': continue lower_line = line.lower() if in_params is False: param_pos = lower_line.find("parameters:") if param_pos >= 0: in_params = True continue if curr_name is None: curr_name_start = line_len - len(line.lstrip()) line = line.lstrip() curr_name = line.rstrip(':') continue curr_line_start = line_len - len(line.lstrip()) if curr_line_start <= param_pos: if curr_name is not None: var_list.append([curr_name, curr_type, curr_default, curr_desc]) break if curr_line_start <= curr_name_start: if curr_name is not None: var_list.append([curr_name, curr_type, curr_default, curr_desc]) curr_name_start = curr_line_start curr_name = line.rstrip(':') curr_name = curr_name.lstrip() curr_type = None curr_desc = None curr_default = None continue val_pos = lower_line.find("type:") if val_pos != -1: curr_type = line[(curr_line_start + len("type:")):] curr_type = curr_type.lstrip() continue val_pos = lower_line.find("default:") if val_pos != -1: curr_default = line[(curr_line_start + len("default:")):] curr_default = curr_default.lstrip() continue val_pos = lower_line.find("description:") if val_pos != -1: curr_desc = line[(curr_line_start + len("description:")):] curr_desc = curr_desc.lstrip() continue var_list.sort() return var_list if __name__ == "__main__": # ***** Mistral Task parsing ***** import sys if len(sys.argv) < 3: sys.exit("Parameter 1 is a Mistral DSL, parameter 2 is a HoT") FILE_LIST = [] with open(sys.argv[1], "r") as fileptr: for lineval in fileptr: FILE_LIST.append(lineval) RET_TASK_LIST = get_mistral_task_list(FILE_LIST) print "
Mistral DSL ordered task list:" for counter in range(len(RET_TASK_LIST)): print "Task #%d: %s | on success -> %s, on error -> %s" % ( counter, RET_TASK_LIST[counter][0], RET_TASK_LIST[counter][1], RET_TASK_LIST[counter][2]) # ***** Mistral required input list ***** FILE_LIST = [] with open(sys.argv[1], "r") as fileptr: for lineval in fileptr: FILE_LIST.append(lineval) print "
Mistral DSL required user input list:" INPUT_LIST, OUT_LIST = get_mistral_required_input(FILE_LIST) for var in INPUT_LIST: print "* " + var print "
Mistral output values which need no user input:" for var in OUT_LIST: print "* " + var # ***** Heat required input list ***** FILE_LIST = [] with open(sys.argv[2], "r") as fileptr: for lineval in fileptr: FILE_LIST.append(lineval) print "
Heat template required user input list:" INPUT_LIST = get_heat_required_input(FILE_LIST) for var in INPUT_LIST: print "* Name: %s, type: %s, default: %s, description: %s" % ( var[0], var[1], var[2], var[3])

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2011 X.commerce, a business unit of eBay Inc. # Copyright 2010 United States Government as represented by the # Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Defines interface for image transfer. """ from oslo.config import cfg from nova.openstack.common import log as logging from nova.openstack.common import importutils protocol_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('transfer_driver', default='nova.image.http.Http', help='This is the driver to implement a transfer protocol.'), ] CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(protocol_opts, 'protocol') class ImageTransferAPI(object): """Image transfer API wrapper class. """ def __init__(self, transferDriver=None): if transferDriver: self._transferDriver = transferDriver self._transferDriver = importutils.import_object( CONF.protocol.transfer_driver) def copyFrom(self, resource_uri, **kwargs): """Copy the image from a remote site. resource_uri is uri for the image resource to access. image_chunks_from_library is used to keep the image data from the remote site. """ return self._transferDriver.copyFrom(resource_uri, **kwargs) def sendTo(self, resource_uri, image_data, **kwargs): """Send the image to a remote site. resource_uri is uri for the image resource to access. image_data is the image data to send. """ self._transferDriver.sendTo(resource_uri, image_data, **kwargs) ITP = ImageTransferAPI() LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def copyFrom(resource_uri, **kwargs): """Copy the image from a remote site.""" return ITP.copyFrom(resource_uri, **kwargs) def sendTo(resource_uri, image_data, **kwargs): """Send the image to a remote site. """ return ITP.sendTo(resource_uri, image_data, **kwargs)

Corrected a simple typo in OSSN-0021

There was a simple typo in the recently merged version of OSSN-0021.
I caught and corrected it before publishing, but it should also be
corrected in tree.

Server snapshot support

This patch is server snapshot support implementation for vmwmare
hypervisor.

Implements: blueprint driver-specific-snapshot
Change-Id: I7a2b437a87d25139f3ad534a273926de21a5db9f

commit_message:
Fix default_volume_type for Cinder multi backend

The default_volume_type option doesn't support comma separated
arguments. We can only select one default volume type.
We have a variable that contains the default volume type, so we simply use it.

Closes-Bug: 1342569

Change-Id: Ibd080442f00f3d446ec374fc5906f0778d449007
Signed-off-by: Sébastien Han <sebastien.han@enovance.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/48/107248/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(leseb): we pick the first backend from the list. iniset $CINDER_CONF DEFAULT default_volume_type $(echo ${enabled_backends} | cut -f1 -d',')

commit_message:
timeutils function retry_backoff_delay

Calculates an exponential backoff delay with jitter for retrying
operations which might fail.

The exponential delay on each attempt gives the service a chance
to process its backlog of retries after it starts responding again.

The jitter adds some randomness to the delay to prevent
multiple synchronised backoff retries from hitting the
service at exactly the same time.

The next change in this series makes use of this function.

Change-Id: Ie209ef62c0da68a5b503354764e5add2b6e5569a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/77/108477/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import random def retry_backoff_delay(attempt, exp_mult=1.0, jitter_max=0.0): """ Calculate an exponential backoff delay with jitter. :param attempt: The count of the current retry attempt :param exp_mult: Multiplier to scale the exponential delay by :param jitter_max: Maximum of random seconds to add to the delay :returns: Seconds since epoch to wait until """ exp = float(2 ** attempt) * float(exp_mult) if jitter_max == 0.0: return exp return exp + random.random() * jitter_max

commit_message:
VPNaaS: Separate validation for Cisco impl

Moving validation logic from Cisco service driver, into a
validation subclass, so that it'll be applied during the
persistence phase (so validation failures can block the
persistence, instead of setting to error state).

This is part of the effort to separate out L3 validation
and builds upon the reference implementation changes being
reviewed in 102351.

Note: One unit test is commented out, due to a bug in
oslo.messaging 1.3.0. It will be uncommented later, once
1.4.0.0.a3 or newer is available for use.

Change-Id: I6040e6d8ab32b707bcf67a0882507b7ee2d4bebe
Partial-Implementation: blueprint l3-svcs-vendor-validation
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/73/107473/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Cisco Systems, Inc. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # @author: Paul Michali, Cisco Systems, Inc. import netaddr from netaddr import core as net_exc from neutron.common import exceptions from neutron.db.vpn import vpn_validator from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging LIFETIME_LIMITS = {'IKE Policy': {'min': 60, 'max': 86400}, 'IPSec Policy': {'min': 120, 'max': 2592000}} MIN_CSR_MTU = 1500 MAX_CSR_MTU = 9192 LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class CsrValidationFailure(exceptions.BadRequest): message = _("Cisco CSR does not support %(resource)s attribute %(key)s " "with value '%(value)s'") class CiscoCsrVpnValidator(vpn_validator.VpnReferenceValidator): """Validator methods for the Cisco CSR.""" def __init__(self, service_plugin): self.service_plugin = service_plugin super(CiscoCsrVpnValidator, self).__init__() def validate_lifetime(self, for_policy, policy_info): """Ensure lifetime in secs and value is supported, based on policy.""" units = policy_info['lifetime']['units'] if units != 'seconds': raise CsrValidationFailure(resource=for_policy, key='lifetime:units', value=units) value = policy_info['lifetime']['value'] if (value < LIFETIME_LIMITS[for_policy]['min'] or value > LIFETIME_LIMITS[for_policy]['max']): raise CsrValidationFailure(resource=for_policy, key='lifetime:value', value=value) def validate_ike_version(self, policy_info): """Ensure IKE policy is v1 for current REST API.""" version = policy_info['ike_version'] if version != 'v1': raise CsrValidationFailure(resource='IKE Policy', key='ike_version', value=version) def validate_mtu(self, conn_info): """Ensure the MTU value is supported.""" mtu = conn_info['mtu'] if mtu < MIN_CSR_MTU or mtu > MAX_CSR_MTU: raise CsrValidationFailure(resource='IPSec Connection', key='mtu', value=mtu) def validate_public_ip_present(self, vpn_service): """Ensure there is one gateway IP specified for the router used.""" gw_port = vpn_service.router.gw_port if not gw_port or len(gw_port.fixed_ips) != 1: raise CsrValidationFailure(resource='IPSec Connection', key='router:gw_port:ip_address', value='missing') def validate_peer_id(self, ipsec_conn): """Ensure that an IP address is specified for peer ID.""" # TODO(pcm) Should we check peer_address too? peer_id = ipsec_conn['peer_id'] try: netaddr.IPAddress(peer_id) except net_exc.AddrFormatError: raise CsrValidationFailure(resource='IPSec Connection', key='peer_id', value=peer_id) def validate_ipsec_site_connection(self, context, ipsec_sitecon, ip_version): """Validate IPSec site connection for Cisco CSR. After doing reference validation, do additional checks that relate to the Cisco CSR. """ super(CiscoCsrVpnValidator, self)._check_dpd(ipsec_sitecon) ike_policy = self.service_plugin.get_ikepolicy( context, ipsec_sitecon['ikepolicy_id']) ipsec_policy = self.service_plugin.get_ipsecpolicy( context, ipsec_sitecon['ipsecpolicy_id']) vpn_service = self.service_plugin.get_vpnservice( context, ipsec_sitecon['vpnservice_id']) self.validate_lifetime('IKE Policy', ike_policy) self.validate_lifetime('IPSec Policy', ipsec_policy) self.validate_ike_version(ike_policy) self.validate_mtu(ipsec_sitecon) self.validate_public_ip_present(vpn_service) self.validate_peer_id(ipsec_sitecon) LOG.debug("IPSec connection %s validated for Cisco CSR", ipsec_sitecon['id'])

commit_message:
Add support for new fields in network create

Also adds missing network-delete shell command. Additionally changes
the type of vlan and vlan_start to int to match the api samples.

Partially-implements blueprint better-support-for-multiple-networks

Change-Id: I233614431db4737284cceaf8e6b947f50dd84602

commit_message:
changed openvswitch version check command

the result of command "modinfo openvswitch"
contains no version info anymore, so added
the way to get the version info of ovs.
"ovs-vswitchd --version" which is runnable
by anyone on linux (w/o sudo command)

Change-Id: Ia09b7357e25fc172efab088990ce12d1a77af739
Closes-Bug: #1322139
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/15/98615/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: args = ["ovs-vswitchd", "--version"] if 'ovs-vswitchd ' in line:
deleted_lines: args = ["modinfo", "openvswitch"] if 'version: ' in line and not 'srcversion' in line:

commit_message:
Add X-Auth-Token header in federation examples

cURL examples depicting fetching accessible projects and domains upon
successfull retrieving federated unscoped token should also include
``X-Auth-Token`` header.
This patch adds headers to the examples.

Change-Id: I463e34511b8f9b19012fce955f04a0269d5de9cd
Closes-Bug: #1348680
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/14/109614/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $ curl -X GET -H "X-Auth-Token: <unscoped token>" http://localhost:5000/v3/OS-FEDERATION/projects $ curl -X GET -H "X-Auth-Token: <unscoped token>" http://localhost:5000/v3/OS-FEDERATION/domains

commit_message:
Enable H233

H233 (and H402) were temporarily disabled as part of the migration to
hacking 0.9. This patch fixes all H233 issues and re-enables
gating on them.

H402 has been removed in hacking
(I9426644fa708e9d5563abe04dc4ad656dbeb3656) so leave this one off as its
going away anyway.

Change-Id: Iae8f132c66c5e345dc2e9c2464f67609887c1475

commit_message:
Fixing up getting started instructions

When installing on a clean machine, the README
and requirements.txt was inadequate for getting the tests running.

This change fixes up those instructions.

Change-Id: Idba5053e29632bb1295fb6b2148a9f59503435d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/36/109136/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 0. Install requirements. - python 2.7 or above https://www.python.org/download/releases/2.7/ - pip https://pip.pypa.io/en/latest/installing.html - java http://java.com 1. Setup Congress cd /path/to/congress sudo python setup.py develop 2. Run the unit tests cd /path/to/congress ./run_tests.sh -N 3. Run the API server: cd /path/to/congress ./bin/congress-server --config-file etc/congress.conf.sample 4. Read docs Open /path/to/congress/doc/html/index.html in a browser
deleted_lines: 1. Compile: - from the root directory make 2. Run the API server: - from the root directory ./bin/congress-server --config-file congress/etc/congress.sample.conf 3. Run the unit tests - from the root directory tox -epy27 or via ./run_test.sh

commit_message:
Initial centos7 support

Initial support for a centos7 image.

This is separate to rhel7 because the major differences are things
like repo and image locations, which are always going to be different.
We should merge any real changes into the redhat-common layers.

Apart from the added support files in centos7/*, the other change is
mostly modifications to redhat-common's extract-image to handle
different partition layouts of the centos7 image.

Change-Id: I943abe5ff0a803f36eda266a79af0d9220edcae7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/49/104449/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Use Centos 7 cloud images as the baseline for built disk images. Note: this is very early beta at this point For further details see the redhat-common README.

commit_message:
Handle non-script grub2-install

grub2-install has been re-written [1] so isn't always a shell script,
so just exec it directly.  Also use $() as that follows the rest of
the file.

[1] http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/grub.git/commit?id=cd46aa6cefabd7b0fcb15cd614577e1ab8c7a841

Change-Id: Ib4fd7c6854fb485c0da6a79babf4a3d45a8a0f2c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/12/106912/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: GRUBNAME=$(which grub-install) || echo "trying grub2-install" GRUBNAME=$(which grub2-install)
deleted_lines: GRUBNAME=`which grub-install` || echo "trying grub2-install" GRUBNAME="bash -x `which grub2-install`"

subject: Don't log message for keystone ID query when supressing exceptions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-23 16:53:44.000000000', 'files': ['barbican/model/repositories.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican/commit/ed5eab5f53e26700ee9e78249f5840440405703e', 'message': 'Don't log message for keystone ID query when supressing exceptions

Barbican repo method find_by_keystone_id will check the DB for a
tenant ID.  It also takes a flag, supress_exception, so that a
"tenant not found" type of error won't result in an exception
being percolated to its caller.

When the query is done for a tenant that has never been used
it will raise a NoResultFound which gets caught and only
percolated if the supress_exception flag is false.

Previous to this change, we would log this NoResultFound which
in many cases is expected behaviour (hence the supress_exception
flag).  This could be confusing for someone looking at barbican
logs (or an automated log crawler) since this exception is actually
expected behaviour.

This change moves the logging of the exception so that it only
happens if the supress_exception flag is false.  This keeps these
expected exceptions out of the logs.

Change-Id: I864ab7db19efb2230f43c9287103b97fa7b16beb
Closes-Bug: 1347205
'}]
commit_message:
Don't log message for keystone ID query when supressing exceptions

Barbican repo method find_by_keystone_id will check the DB for a
tenant ID.  It also takes a flag, supress_exception, so that a
"tenant not found" type of error won't result in an exception
being percolated to its caller.

When the query is done for a tenant that has never been used
it will raise a NoResultFound which gets caught and only
percolated if the supress_exception flag is false.

Previous to this change, we would log this NoResultFound which
in many cases is expected behaviour (hence the supress_exception
flag).  This could be confusing for someone looking at barbican
logs (or an automated log crawler) since this exception is actually
expected behaviour.

This change moves the logging of the exception so that it only
happens if the supress_exception flag is false.  This keeps these
expected exceptions out of the logs.

Change-Id: I864ab7db19efb2230f43c9287103b97fa7b16beb
Closes-Bug: 1347205
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/37/109037/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.exception("Problem getting Tenant {0}".format(keystone_id))

commit_message:
Set rgw host to short hostname

The radosgw init script on CentOS checks the short hostname
with the one defined in /etc/ceph/ceph.conf. If these don't
match radosgw won't be started.

Change-Id: I215284c0ea24ac4469132c0e34f51bba8357b717
Closes-bug: #1348730
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/69/109669/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-24 14:40:52.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/services/orchestration/json/orchestration_client.py', 'tempest/api/orchestration/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/6149e1a24f159303d2c3ec412a64a8a9c5030260', 'message': "orchestration: tolerate NotFound in wait_for_stack_status

so catch the exception and return in that case, to avoid needing

commit_message:
orchestration: tolerate NotFound in wait_for_stack_status

When waiting for a stack to transition to DELETE_COMPLETE status
it's possible to either get that status, or a NotFound exception
so catch the exception and return in that case, to avoid needing
try/except around the wait, or risking races in tests which wait
for DELETE_COMPLETE without a try/except (test_volumes.py)

Change-Id: I4ded172db3c8969075365a0dc6b60d8e3e7db71d
Partial-Bug: #1344989
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/08/109308/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cls.client.wait_for_stack_status( stack_identifier, 'DELETE_COMPLETE')
deleted_lines: try: cls.client.wait_for_stack_status( stack_identifier, 'DELETE_COMPLETE') except exceptions.NotFound: pass

commit_message:
Make the i18n integration module private

Rename oslo.utils.i18n to oslo.utils._i18n to highlight the fact that it
is an implementation detail and should not be imported and used by
consumers of oslo.utils.

Change-Id: Ib271f7e1216e3c865929d39749a9fb96237ad4f2

commit_message:
Reserve the keystone high port out of ephemeral

The Keystone high port of 35357 is within the range Linux uses as
the ephemeral port range to reply to connections. Reserve it by
utilising the sysctl element.

Change-Id: I88cef5d95820e1ccf9501ef15ca2ace6efb516c3
Closes-Bug: #1330289

added_lines: # Reserve the Keystone port out of the ephemeral port range. sysctl-set-value net.ipv4.ip_local_reserved_ports 35357

Use auth_token from keystonemiddleware

auth_token middleware in python-keystoneclient is deprecated and has
been moved to the keystonemiddleware repo.

commit_message:
OSSN-0021 - Keystone trusts on compromised account

Adding a description of the issue of verifying Keystone trust in case
of account compromise. Including examples of API interaction to help
check the situation.

Closes-Bug: #1341849
Change-Id: Iaf38c214d553dfd4dfe29dac9dc1496c061fb765
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/openstack-security-notes refs/changes/26/107426/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Compromised account owners should verify Keystone trusts --- ### Summary ### The new system of granting trusts allows creating ways to access the account which may not be easily noticed when the account is compromised. ### Affected Services / Software ### Keystone, Juno ### Discussion ### The Keystone trusts system allows delegating access to people and services without giving away the main token, or sharing the account secret key with them. That means, after an account is compromised, the change of the secret key and the invalidation of existing tokens may not be enought to prevent future access from the attackers. The attacker could create Keystone trusts, granting themselves access which does not depend on knowing the account's secret key and does not expire. If that is the case, the trust has to be manually found and removed by the account owner. Information about the using trusts can be found at: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Keystone/Trusts ### Recommended Actions ### If the account has been compromised, or is being audited, the owner should check the list of active trusts and verify: - if all the active trusts are needed, and - if all the active trusts have the expected roles and delegation depth ### Contacts / References ### This OSSN : https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0021 Original LaunchPad Bug : https://bugs.launchpad.net/ossn/+bug/1341849 OpenStack Security ML : openstack-security@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg

subject: Revamp the symbol lookup mechanism
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-22 04:23:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/f3abee4136b713006c541a5c914cc9668c495914', 'message': 'Revamp the symbol lookup mechanism

To complement the adjusted changes in patterns we also want
to allow the execution of patterns to be affected in a similar
manner so that symbol lookup is no longer as restrictive as it
was.

This change adds in the following:

- Symbol lookup by examining atom predecessors.
- Better error messaging when symbols are not found.
- Adjusted tests (existing ones work).

Part of blueprint taskflow-improved-scoping

commit_message:
Revamp the symbol lookup mechanism

To complement the adjusted changes in patterns we also want
to allow the execution of patterns to be affected in a similar
manner so that symbol lookup is no longer as restrictive as it
was prior to these changes.

This change adds in the following:

- Symbol lookup by walking through an atoms contained scope/s.
- Better error messaging when symbols are not found.
- Adjusted & new tests (existing ones work).
- Better logging of the symbol lookup mechanism (helpful
  during debugging, although it is very verbose...)

Part of blueprint taskflow-improved-scoping

Change-Id: I146d4d24b7e21b6613ae33541edb5e1434635be9

commit_message:
Fix SSL with HAProxy.

The current configuration of services is that if SSL is in use (signaled by
stunnel.connect_ip) we bind to 127.0.0.1 - which is great, but it breaks
simultaneous non-SSL due to there being no pass-through stunnel equivalent on
all the nodes. As an interim measure, teach stunnel to connect to the ctlplane
address instead. We will need this flexability in future anyway to deal with
mixed-mode configurations, but we don't yet have an SSL only configuration.

The change will permit SSL only by altering the Deployment object only - the
SSL config object should now be flexible enough to run in either mode (but as
yet on an all-one-way-or-the-other basis).

Change-Id: Ibac3dec1fe7b573029482fdd9ad2d2f6223fbce0

commit_message:
Permit specification of host in stunnel templates

While we can in principle do this already, there is a bug (1344284)
in heat which breaks our ability to calculate an appropriate unified
line from within heat. Instead, we can pass separate metadata to
os-apply-config and avoid this bug (which has no straight forward
fix).

Change-Id: I820862982afee07d85f1f0ad02b08cd5b0f35e49
Related-Bug: #1344284

commit_message:
Clean up EP-Filter after delete project/endpoint

For endpoint_filter extension we should remove all the endpoint
to project associations when we delete the associated endpoint
or project. Otherwise list_endpoints_for_project and
list_projects_for_endpoint API will return 404 response if the
associated endpoint or project has been deleted. Also, there will
be a lot of dirty data remaining in the database.

Change-Id: I48e9100a8fa92d10b7ffe5f89bfb8ba9cf78a0e7
Closes-Bug: #1305537

added_lines: from keystone import notifications def __init__(self): super(EndpointFilterV3Controller, self).__init__() notifications.register_event_callback( 'deleted', 'project', self._on_project_or_endpoint_delete) notifications.register_event_callback( 'deleted', 'endpoint', self._on_project_or_endpoint_delete) def _on_project_or_endpoint_delete(self, service, resource_type, operation, payload): project_or_endpoint_id = payload['resource_info'] if resource_type == 'project': self.endpoint_filter_api.delete_association_by_project( project_or_endpoint_id) else: self.endpoint_filter_api.delete_association_by_endpoint( project_or_endpoint_id)

commit_message:
Add conntrack-tools to nova dependencies

'Error deleting conntrack entries' appears in all
n-net. Adding conntrack-tools/conntrack as nova dependency,
in order to eliminate this issue.

Change-Id: Ief9deeb3349a07e22fb365e58f3368c847f845ef

commit_message:
Add the 'auth' interface type

There are certain requests that will always want to be sent to the
auth_url.

Add a new interface type to the get_endpoint command of the base
identity plugin such that if you ask for the 'auth' interface it will
give you the auth_url.

Implements: blueprint session-auth-endpoint
Change-Id: If653970354b919fdd6e80c061611c3aad129c574

commit_message:
Improve warning when TRIPLEO_ROOT is defaulted

The warning when TRIPLEO_ROOT was left to default to ~/.cache/tripleo
did not make it clear that other environment variables are also given
defaults based on that value. So just resetting TRIPLEO_ROOT would
not be enough to give you a working system.

This patch just makes the warning a bit clearer.

Change-Id: Idb1091c252ac83f728cb5734884c5992dd0a1754
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/23/108923/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo " Other environement variables are based on \$TRIPLEO_ROOT so" echo " if you intend changing it, please source devtest_variables.sh" echo " again afterwards."

commit_message:
Provide openstack-dn2osdbk

This tool converts docutils native XML to docbook. The conversion is
done using XSLT, with some custom XML treatment.

The XSL source is a slightly modified version of Dn2dbk written by Éric
Bellot (http://ebellot.chez.com/dn2dbk/index.htm).

Modify doctest to check and build the HOT guide.

Implements: blueprint heat-templates

Change-Id: If866a5ffe19165c38981493684de550e0df0e36d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/34/108034/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
added support for complex characters without quote

changed to accept numbers as leading characters
Change-Id: I8881b149b6248184df5c25b20e60b9415a9513be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-common refs/changes/32/109532/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .put("url", "\"https://www.google.com/?startpage=3&happygoing\"") .put("specialchars", "\"!@#$%^&*()~<>{}[],.\"") public void shouldParseComplexWithoutQuotes() { AlarmExpression expr = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=1, url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2F%3Fstartpage%3D3%26happygoing}, 1) > 5 times 3 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem, specialchars=a!@#/\\$%^*~}, 2) < 4 times 3"); List<AlarmSubExpression> alarms = expr.getSubExpressions(); AlarmExpression containsDirectories = new AlarmExpression("avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=1,global=$_globalVariable,special=__useSparingly,dos=C:\\system32\\}, 1) > 5 times 3 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem,$globalVariable=global,__useSparingly=special,unix=/opt/vertica/bin/}, 2) < 4 times 3"); List<AlarmSubExpression> alarmsContainsDirectories = containsDirectories.getSubExpressions(); AlarmSubExpression expected1 = new AlarmSubExpression(AggregateFunction.AVG, new MetricDefinition("hpcs.compute", ImmutableMap.<String, String>builder() .put("instance_id", "5") .put("metric_name", "cpu") .put("url", "https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2F%3Fstartpage%3D3%26happygoing") .put("device", "1") .build()), AlarmOperator.GT, 5, 1, 3); AlarmSubExpression expected2 = new AlarmSubExpression(AggregateFunction.AVG, new MetricDefinition("hpcs.compute", ImmutableMap.<String, String>builder() .put("flavor_id", "3") .put("metric_name", "mem") .put("specialchars", "a!@#/\\$%^*~") .build()), AlarmOperator.LT, 4, 2, 3); AlarmSubExpression expected3 = new AlarmSubExpression(AggregateFunction.AVG, new MetricDefinition("hpcs.compute", ImmutableMap.<String, String>builder() .put("instance_id", "5") .put("metric_name", "cpu") .put("device", "1") .put("global", "$_globalVariable") .put("special", "__useSparingly") .put("dos", "C:\\system32\\") .build()), AlarmOperator.GT, 5, 1, 3); AlarmSubExpression expected4 = new AlarmSubExpression(AggregateFunction.AVG, new MetricDefinition("hpcs.compute", ImmutableMap.<String, String>builder() .put("flavor_id", "3") .put("metric_name", "mem") .put("$globalVariable", "global") .put("__useSparingly", "special") .put("unix", "/opt/vertica/bin/") .build()), AlarmOperator.LT, 4, 2, 3); assertEquals(alarms.get(0), expected1); assertEquals(alarms.get(1), expected2); assertEquals(alarmsContainsDirectories.get(0), expected3); assertEquals(alarmsContainsDirectories.get(1), expected4); } public void shouldParseExpressionWithoutType() { AlarmExpression expr = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=1}, 1) > 5 times 3 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) < 4 times 3"); List<AlarmSubExpression> alarms = expr.getSubExpressions(); AlarmSubExpression expected1 = new AlarmSubExpression(AggregateFunction.AVG, new MetricDefinition("hpcs.compute", ImmutableMap.<String, String>builder() .put("instance_id", "5") .put("metric_name", "cpu") .put("device", "1") .build()), AlarmOperator.GT, 5, 1, 3); AlarmSubExpression expected2 = new AlarmSubExpression(AggregateFunction.AVG, new MetricDefinition("hpcs.compute", ImmutableMap.<String, String>builder() .put("flavor_id", "3") .put("metric_name", "mem") .build()), AlarmOperator.LT, 4, 2, 3); assertEquals(alarms.get(0), expected1); assertEquals(alarms.get(1), expected2); } public void shouldEvaluateExpression() { AlarmExpression expr = new AlarmExpression( "sum(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=disk}, 1) > 33 or (avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=1}, 1) > 5 times 3 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) < 4 times 3)"); List<AlarmSubExpression> alarms = expr.getSubExpressions(); AlarmSubExpression alarm1 = alarms.get(0); AlarmSubExpression alarm2 = alarms.get(1); AlarmSubExpression alarm3 = alarms.get(2); assertTrue(expr.evaluate(ImmutableMap.<AlarmSubExpression, Boolean>builder() .put(alarm1, true) .put(alarm2, false) .put(alarm3, false) .build())); assertTrue(expr.evaluate(ImmutableMap.<AlarmSubExpression, Boolean>builder() .put(alarm1, false) .put(alarm2, true) .put(alarm3, true) .build())); assertFalse(expr.evaluate(ImmutableMap.<AlarmSubExpression, Boolean>builder() .put(alarm1, false) .put(alarm2, false) .put(alarm3, true) .build())); assertFalse(expr.evaluate(ImmutableMap.<AlarmSubExpression, Boolean>builder() .put(alarm1, false) .put(alarm2, true) .put(alarm3, false) .build())); } public void shouldDefaultPeriodAndPeriods() { AlarmExpression expr = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=1}) > 5"); AlarmSubExpression alarm = expr.getSubExpressions().get(0); assertEquals(alarm.getPeriod(), 60); assertEquals(alarm.getPeriods(), 1); } @Test(expectedExceptions = IllegalArgumentException.class) public void shouldThrowOnEvaluateInvalidSubExpressions() { AlarmExpression expr = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=2}, 1) > 5 times 3 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) < 4 times 3"); expr.evaluate(ImmutableMap.<AlarmSubExpression, Boolean>builder() .put( new AlarmSubExpression(AggregateFunction.AVG, new MetricDefinition("hpcs.compute", ImmutableMap.<String, String>builder() .put("flavor_id", "3") .put("metric_name", "mem") .build()), AlarmOperator.LT, 4, 2, 3), true) .build()); } public void shouldGetAlarmExpressionTree() { Object expr = AlarmExpression.of( "(avg(foo) > 1 and avg(bar) < 2 and avg(baz) > 3) or (avg(foo) > 4 and avg(bar) < 5 and avg(baz) > 6)") .getExpressionTree(); assertEquals( expr.toString(), "((avg(foo) > 1.0 AND avg(bar) < 2.0 AND avg(baz) > 3.0) OR (avg(foo) > 4.0 AND avg(bar) < 5.0 AND avg(baz) > 6.0))"); expr = AlarmExpression.of( "(avg(foo) > 1 and (avg(bar) < 2 or avg(baz) > 3)) and (avg(foo) > 4 or avg(bar) < 5 or avg(baz) > 6)") .getExpressionTree(); assertEquals( expr.toString(), "(avg(foo) > 1.0 AND (avg(bar) < 2.0 OR avg(baz) > 3.0) AND (avg(foo) > 4.0 OR avg(bar) < 5.0 OR avg(baz) > 6.0))"); } @Test(enabled = false) public void testExpressionEquality() { AlarmExpression expr1 = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=a}, 1) lt 5 times 3 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) < 4 times 3"); AlarmExpression expr2 = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) gt 3 times 3 && avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=a}, 1) lt 5 times 3"); assertEquals(expr1, expr2); AlarmExpression expr3 = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=a}, 1) lt 5 times 444 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) < 4 times 3"); assertNotEquals(expr1, expr3); }

AlarmSubExpression expected2 = new AlarmSubExpression(AggregateFunction.AVG, new MetricDefinition("hpcs.compute", ImmutableMap.<String, String>builder() .put("flavor_id", "3") .put("metric_name", "mem") .build()), AlarmOperator.LT, 4, 2, 3); assertEquals(alarms.get(0), expected1); assertEquals(alarms.get(1), expected2); } public void shouldEvaluateExpression() { AlarmExpression expr = new AlarmExpression( "sum(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=disk}, 1) > 33 or (avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=1}, 1) > 5 times 3 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) < 4 times 3)"); List<AlarmSubExpression> alarms = expr.getSubExpressions(); AlarmSubExpression alarm1 = alarms.get(0); AlarmSubExpression alarm2 = alarms.get(1); AlarmSubExpression alarm3 = alarms.get(2); assertTrue(expr.evaluate(ImmutableMap.<AlarmSubExpression, Boolean>builder() .put(alarm1, true) .put(alarm2, false) .put(alarm3, false) .build())); assertTrue(expr.evaluate(ImmutableMap.<AlarmSubExpression, Boolean>builder() .put(alarm1, false) .put(alarm2, true) .put(alarm3, true) .build())); assertFalse(expr.evaluate(ImmutableMap.<AlarmSubExpression, Boolean>builder() .put(alarm1, false) .put(alarm2, false) .put(alarm3, true) .build())); assertFalse(expr.evaluate(ImmutableMap.<AlarmSubExpression, Boolean>builder() .put(alarm1, false) .put(alarm2, true) .put(alarm3, false) .build())); } public void shouldDefaultPeriodAndPeriods() { AlarmExpression expr = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=1}) > 5"); AlarmSubExpression alarm = expr.getSubExpressions().get(0); assertEquals(alarm.getPeriod(), 60); assertEquals(alarm.getPeriods(), 1); } @Test(expectedExceptions = IllegalArgumentException.class) public void shouldThrowOnEvaluateInvalidSubExpressions() { AlarmExpression expr = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=2}, 1) > 5 times 3 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) < 4 times 3"); expr.evaluate(ImmutableMap.<AlarmSubExpression, Boolean>builder() .put( new AlarmSubExpression(AggregateFunction.AVG, new MetricDefinition("hpcs.compute", ImmutableMap.<String, String>builder() .put("flavor_id", "3") .put("metric_name", "mem") .build()), AlarmOperator.LT, 4, 2, 3), true) .build()); } public void shouldGetAlarmExpressionTree() { Object expr = AlarmExpression.of( "(avg(foo) > 1 and avg(bar) < 2 and avg(baz) > 3) or (avg(foo) > 4 and avg(bar) < 5 and avg(baz) > 6)") .getExpressionTree(); assertEquals( expr.toString(), "((avg(foo) > 1.0 AND avg(bar) < 2.0 AND avg(baz) > 3.0) OR (avg(foo) > 4.0 AND avg(bar) < 5.0 AND avg(baz) > 6.0))"); expr = AlarmExpression.of( "(avg(foo) > 1 and (avg(bar) < 2 or avg(baz) > 3)) and (avg(foo) > 4 or avg(bar) < 5 or avg(baz) > 6)") .getExpressionTree(); assertEquals( expr.toString(), "(avg(foo) > 1.0 AND (avg(bar) < 2.0 OR avg(baz) > 3.0) AND (avg(foo) > 4.0 OR avg(bar) < 5.0 OR avg(baz) > 6.0))"); } @Test(enabled = false) public void testExpressionEquality() { AlarmExpression expr1 = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=a}, 1) lt 5 times 3 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) < 4 times 3"); AlarmExpression expr2 = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) gt 3 times 3 && avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=a}, 1) lt 5 times 3"); assertEquals(expr1, expr2); AlarmExpression expr3 = new AlarmExpression( "avg(hpcs.compute{instance_id=5,metric_name=cpu,device=a}, 1) lt 5 times 444 and avg(hpcs.compute{flavor_id=3,metric_name=mem}, 2) < 4 times 3"); assertNotEquals(expr1, expr3); }

commit_message:
Move te-broker default IP address to 1.254

We're moving it to the end of the range to make deploys easier.
At the low end it races with dhcp agents and so forth.

Change-Id: I34600d127ff5b43c775bea07f7217cdc875b8e6a

commit_message:
Add script to prepare a ci-overcloud

Script what needs to be done in order to prepare a ci-overcloud for CI
Currently a WIP, a few things still need to be ironed out. Also run this
at the end of deploy-ci-overcloud, it currenlty hardcoded to the HP
region but so it the rest of deploy-ci-overcloud.

Co-Authored-By: Robert Collins <rbtcollins@hp.com>
Change-Id: I461a840710625294a2aef1a1e08a3ed852e946ab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/46/90146/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # # This is a helper to get tripleo-cd admins to prepare a ci-overcloud for CI repeatably. set -eux set -o pipefail # TODO : update config/*rc file to hold rack specific settings for Distro/Quotas/whatever .... source $1 NODEPOOLTENANTID=$(keystone tenant-list | awk '$4=="openstack-nodepool" {print $2}') neutron net-create tripleo-bm-test --tenant-id $NODEPOOLTENANTID --provider:network_type flat --provider:physical_network tripleo-bm-test TESTNETID=$(neutron net-show tripleo-bm-test | awk '$2=="id" {print $4}') neutron subnet-create --ip_version 4 --tenant-id $NODEPOOLTENANTID --allocation-pool start=192.168.1.1,end=192.168.1.254 --no-gateway $TESTNETID 192.168.1.0/24 # update subnet of default-net DEFAULTSUBNETID=$(neutron net-show default-net | awk '$2=="subnets" {print $4}') neutron subnet-update $DEFAULTSUBNETID --dns-nameservers list=true 8.8.8.8 keystone user-role-add --role Member --user tripleo-ci --tenant openstack-nodepool curl http://mirrors.nebo.edu/public/fedora/linux/releases/20/Images/x86_64/Fedora-x86_64-20-20131211.1-sda.qcow2 > $TRIPLEO_ROOT/Fedora-x86_64-20-20131211.1-sda.qcow2 curl http://cloud-images.ubuntu.com/precise/20140306/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-disk1.img > $TRIPLEO_ROOT/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-disk1.img glance image-create --name "Fedora 20 64-bit" --disk-format qcow2 --container-format bare --is-public 1 < $TRIPLEO_ROOT/Fedora-x86_64-20-20131211.1-sda.qcow2 glance image-create --name "Ubuntu Precise 12.04 LTS Server 64-bit" --disk-format qcow2 --container-format bare --is-public 1 < $TRIPLEO_ROOT/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-disk1.img # TODO : pick based on rack being used IMAGENAME="Fedora 20 64-bit" USER=fedora read -p "Ubuntu or Fedora ? [u/f] " ANS if [ "$ANS" = "u" ] ; then IMAGENAME="Ubuntu Precise 12.04 LTS Server 64-bit" USER=ubuntu fi NETLIST=$(neutron net-list) DEFAULTNET=$(echo "$NETLIST" | grep default-net | awk '{print $2}') EXTNET=$(echo "$NETLIST" | grep ext-net | awk '{print $2}') # TODO : need to set quotas for the openstack-nodepool tenant # TODO : this should be done as the openstack-nodepool tenant nova boot --image "$IMAGENAME" --flavor m1.small --nic net-id=$DEFAULTNET --nic net-id=$TESTNETID --key-name default te-broker sleep 60 IP=$(nova show $1 | grep "default-net network" | grep -oE "10\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+") PORTID=$(neutron port-list | grep -F "$IP" | awk '{print $2}') FLOATINGIPOUT=$(neutron floatingip-create $EXTNET) FLOATINGIP=$(echo "$FLOATINGIPOUT" | grep floating_ip_address | awk '{print $4}') FLOATINGIPID=$(echo "$FLOATINGIPOUT" | grep " id " | awk '{print $4}') neutron floatingip-associate $FLOATINGIPID $PORTID sleep 90 ssh $USER@$FLOATINGIP <<EOF # manual steps would look like this # TODO but we should use DIB to build an image exit 0 sudo yum install python-virtualenv ; sudo apt-get install python-virtualenv sudo mkdir -p /opt/stack/venvs sudo virtualenv /opt/stack/venvs/gear sudo /opt/stack/venvs/gear/bin/pip install gear sudo useradd gear curl https://raw.github.com/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/master/elements/os-svc-install/bin/os-svc-daemon | sudo dd of=/bin/os-svc-daemon curl https://raw.github.com/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/master/elements/os-svc-install/bin/os-svc-enable | sudo dd of=/bin/os-svc-enable curl https://raw.github.com/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/master/elements/os-svc-install/bin/os-svc-enable-upstart | sudo dd of=/bin/os-svc-enable-upstart curl https://raw.github.com/openstack/diskimage-builder/master/elements/base/dib-init-system | sudo dd of=/bin/dib-init-system sudo chmod +x /bin/os-svc-* /bin/dib-init-system sudo os-svc-daemon -n geard -u gear -c geard -- -d sudo os-svc-enable -n geard sudo service geard start # Fix up eth1 #sudo cp /etc/network/interfaces.d/eth0.cfg /etc/network/interfaces.d/eth1.cfg ; sudo cp /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth1 #sudo vi /etc/network/interfaces.d/eth1.cfg /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth1 #sudo ifup eth1 EOF

commit_message:
Calculate expected number of vcpus/mem

Rather than just wait for a single vcpu or a non-zero amount of
memory to be available, we should look at the baremetal flavor and
figure out how many of each we should expect.

Closes-Bug: #1341634

Change-Id: I9d9ce55de3b9ad0f94d087179b9432e9e9e50d74

commit_message:
Wait longer for BM node registration

At present the code waits for `nova hypervisor-stats` to show the
expected number of nodes are registered. However, at this stage the
nodes can be only partially registered. This means that when the
scheduler is asked for a host, it doesn't know EG that there is ram
available and the ram filter fails.

By also waiting for memory to be registered this patch should improve
the timing characteristics and avoid this failure.

Closes-Bug: 1339532
Change-Id: I2c08bb3dee44f002442fd5c764d5dffed47ee9ba

added_lines: wait_for 20 3 [ nova hypervisor-stats | awk ' $2=="count" && $4 >= '"$expected_nodes"' { c++ }; $2=="memory_mb" && $4 > 0 { c++ }; END { if (c != 2) exit 1 }' ]make -C $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-heat-templates overcloud.yaml
